Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mathematical Modeling and Experimental Study of Femtosecond Laser Machining of High Aspect Ratio Microstructures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this collaborative project is to develop and verify a physics-based model to reveal and quantitatively understand the fundamental physical processes of femtosecond laser-matter interactions in high aspect ratio microstructures. The study employs a combination of experimental and mathematical modeling approaches. Femtosecond laser-matter interactions in high aspect ratio microstructures will be experimentally observed using the pump-probe imaging, optical emission spectroscopy, and other techniques. Important process parameters, such as laser ablation rate, laser- induced plasma (due to the target vaporization and/or hydrodynamic expansion) and shock wave propagation speed, plasma temperature and electron number density, will be measured. The numerical model is based on the solution of Maxwell?s wave equation and hydrodynamic equations, and will be improved and verified by comparing simulations with measurements.

If successfully completed, the benefits of this project will be to set up a solid science base for femtosecond laser-matter interactions in high aspect ratio microstructures. This will establish femtosecond laser micromachining as a direct, flexible, and single-step technology that can realize a precise and controlled production of high-aspect ratio microstructures, which will have a big impact on microelectromechanical system, automotive, aerospace, and optics industries, where the demand for high aspect ratio microstructures has been increasing. The research results will be published in related journals and presented at technical conferences. Direct interactions with companies will be performed for research result dissemination. This interdisciplinary project provides a good opportunity for the training of graduate students. Undergraduate students and students from underrepresented groups will also be involved in the project. Animation demonstration kits based on the project results will be sent to the high schools in the neighborhood of Illinois Institute of Technology, which have high minority enrollment. This will promote the interest of high school students in science and engineering.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this collaborative project is to understand the fundamental physical processes of femtosecond (fs) laser-matter interactions in high aspect ratio microstructures (HARMs), such as deep microholes. The major outcomes and findings of the project are summarized as follows:

 

1.     The effect of HARMs (e.g., a microhole) sidewall on laser beam propagation has been studied. It has been found that when the microhole diameter is sufficiently small as compared with the incoming laser beam diameter, the laser beam profile inside the microhole will be very different from the incoming laser beam. In particular, a linearly polarized axi-symmetric incoming laser beam will change into an elliptical beam profile inside the microhole. Also, a top-flat incoming beam will change into an approximate Gaussian profile inside the microhole. The laser beam profile inside the microhole determines the size and shape of the machined structures, and hence this fundamental study provides valuable scientific guiding information for practical laser micromachining applications.

2.     The interactions between the sidewall of HARMs (e.g., a microhole) and the laser-induced plasma during micromachining have been studied. It has been found that under the typical laser fluences investigated, for a fs laser pulse, the energy transferred from plasma to the sidewall is not sufficient to cause significant material melting, while for a nanosecond (ns) laser pulse at high fluences, obvious melting and vaporization may occur at the sidewall. The study improves our understanding on how laser-induced plasma affects HARMs sidewall, which is a key process in laser machining of HARMs.

3.     The experimental work was focused on investigating a new laser microdrilling technique in which a hollow-core fiber was employed to transmit femtosecond laser pulses to the target position. The laser-fiber coupling efficiency is found to be strongly associated with air breakdown. Outside the breakdown zone, the coupling efficiency remains almost constant at a high value. With a given microhole size and sample thickness, a high ablation rate can be obtained with high pulse energy, a short pulse duration, and a long focal length. The microhole roundness is good with little distortion caused by heat affected zone. The study offers a new technique for microdrilling with high aspect ratio.

 

Intellectual Merit:

As shown above in the project major findings, this study has improved our understanding of laser-material interaction in laser machining of high aspect ratio microstructures, particularly the following three critical processes: (i) the effect of HARMs sidewalls on laser beam propagation, (ii) the laser-induced plasma – sidewall interactions, and (iii) the effects of operating conditions on microdrilling quality. The study has strengthened the scientific base for fs laser machining of HARMs, and the developed models provide useful scientific guiding tools for practical applications. Multiple journal and conference papers have been published (or accepted for publication) based on the research work in this project.

Femtosecond lasers have many other applications which include (but are not limited to): fs laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy, fs laser surgery, thin film deposition, selective machining of thin films in solar cells, synthesis of nanoparticles and nanotubes, and nanomachining, etc. The findings from this project have generated very useful knowledge for the understanding of fs laser-matter interactions in the above-mentioned important applications.

 

Broader Impact:

            The fundamental study in this project provides usef...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The research objective of this collaborative project is to understand the fundamental physical processes of femtosecond (fs) laser-matter interactions in high aspect ratio microstructures (HARMs), such as deep microholes. The major outcomes and findings of the project are summarized as follows: 1. The effect of HARMs (e.g., a microhole) sidewall on laser beam propagation has been studied. It has been found that when the microhole diameter is sufficiently small as compared with the incoming laser beam diameter, the laser beam profile inside the microhole will be very different from the incoming laser beam. In particular, a linearly polarized axi-symmetric incoming laser beam will change into an elliptical beam profile inside the microhole. Also, a top-flat incoming beam will change into an approximate Gaussian profile inside the microhole. The laser beam profile inside the microhole determines the size and shape of the machined structures, and hence this fundamental study provides valuable scientific guiding information for practical laser micromachining applications. 2. The interactions between the sidewall of HARMs (e.g., a microhole) and the laser-induced plasma during micromachining have been studied. It has been found that under the typical laser fluences investigated, for a fs laser pulse, the energy transferred from plasma to the sidewall is not sufficient to cause significant material melting, while for a nanosecond (ns) laser pulse at high fluences, obvious melting and vaporization may occur at the sidewall. The study improves our understanding on how laser-induced plasma affects HARMs sidewall, which is a key process in laser machining of HARMs. 3. The experimental work was focused on investigating a new laser microdrilling technique in which a hollow-core fiber was employed to transmit femtosecond laser pulses to the target position. The laser-fiber coupling efficiency is found to be strongly associated with air breakdown. Outside the breakdown zone, the coupling efficiency remains almost constant at a high value. With a given microhole size and sample thickness, a high ablation rate can be obtained with high pulse energy, a short pulse duration, and a long focal length. The microhole roundness is good with little distortion caused by heat affected zone. The study offers a new technique for microdrilling with high aspect ratio. Intellectual Merit: As shown above in the project major findings, this study has improved our understanding of laser-material interaction in laser machining of high aspect ratio microstructures, particularly the following three critical processes: (i) the effect of HARMs sidewalls on laser beam propagation, (ii) the laser-induced plasma – sidewall interactions, and (iii) the effects of operating conditions on microdrilling quality. The study has strengthened the scientific base for fs laser machining of HARMs, and the developed models provide useful scientific guiding tools for practical applications. Multiple journal and conference papers have been published (or accepted for publication) based on the research work in this project. Femtosecond lasers have many other applications which include (but are not limited to): fs laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy, fs laser surgery, thin film deposition, selective machining of thin films in solar cells, synthesis of nanoparticles and nanotubes, and nanomachining, etc. The findings from this project have generated very useful knowledge for the understanding of fs laser-matter interactions in the above-mentioned important applications. Broader Impact: The fundamental study in this project provides useful scientific information for improving the quality and efficiency, and decreasing the cost in fs laser machining of HARMs. This will benefit the manufacturing of many devices and products in aerospace, automotive, electronics and biomedical areas that need HARMs. This will have a great deal of societal bene...
